Tell HN: LTSE Equity Is Sheisty
text:
Our startup initially chose LTSE Equity [1] for our cap table management. We were told in writing that it is an annual plan that then goes month-to-month.

Fast forward 16 months and we haven't been using it. It's just not that useful of a tool for us, so we are switching to a competitor.

The button to change plans in LTSE's dashboard doesn't work, it just shows a spinner. So we contacted support, who insisted on a meeting before cancelling the plan. We said we are not interested in meeting, and now they are saying our plan is annual, and we have 8 months remaining.

We plan to file chargebacks as we have in writing that the plan is month-to-month, but I wanted the community to know that LTSE Equity uses dark patterns to avoid cancellation, and is doing business dishonestly in general.

[1] https://equity.ltse.com/

Programming Scavenger Hunt
text: about 10 years ago, I did a programming scavenger hunt with my colleagues which was good fun. Every next challenge required you to program a solution. Only when you found the solution, you could move on to the next one. It was very varied. 1 challenge required you to beat the computer in rock/paper/scissors, one required you to look at the ascii codes. Based on this description, is there anybody that can tell me the name of this scavenger hunt?

Insecure Toyota CRM exposed Mexican customer information
Are you worried about your infosec with ChatGPT, or other AI apps?
text:
TLDR:

1. Are you worried about sensitive or restricted data making it to AI providers from employee errors or integration mistakes?

2. If so, how are you stopping sensitive data from reaching your AI providers?

3. Would you be interested in an API or GUI that helped automatically redact or block sensitive data from making it to AI providers?

We’ve heard concerns at two levels of seriousness:

1. Legally controlled data:

- PHI (i.e. health information), SSNs, anything Attorney Client privileged, etc. Here, no matter how good the MSA you have in place is or how reputable the AI provider, you legally cannot share that data.

2. Sensitive/Restricted Internal data:

- Strategic planning documents, financials, customer records, trade secrets, meeting transcripts for sensitive meetings e.t.c. Here, with the right agreements in place with the provider, it’s probably ok to share, but only if all usage is going through a centralized account with firm agreements in place, and even then, you want to be careful.

Now it’s easy to have a rule that says “Don’t put this into AI”, but with employees everywhere using AI for things like meeting notes summarization, a user can just paste an hour long meeting transcript, not realize it has sensitive data in, and then worst case scenario when the provider retrains their model, it puts that information in the hands of other customers/users.

If you have any legally controlled data, or your employees use tools like Chat GPT on personal accounts that haven’t opted out of model training, this seems to be a serious risk.

For example: one of our prospects was using Vowel.com, whose terms of service state they can train models on top of your meeting recordings, with practically 0 restrictions. This could easily end up creating ‘completions’ that regurgitated customer names, strategies, even financials to other companies. Vowel don’t have to be malicious to do this - at scaled usage of AI across many vendors: we think this is inevitable. That’s why security conscious companies like [REDACTED] turned off Chat GPT today.

We’ve been building out tooling to automatically redact keywords, phrases or even entire data sources, from getting to AI apps, enabling them to let users use the AIs without stressing about accidentally leaking customer names, etc, to arbitrary AI apps (example use case automatically translate Cutomer names to their internal codename). This works via our API integration and via our GUI.

We’ve even found this has been really helpful for certain AI companies, who aren’t necessarily set up to handle accidentally getting PII or PHI, and therefore don’t want the risk. To date, this has been a feature in our overall product, but I’m very curious if anyone here would be interested in this specific product as a service of its own?

title: Geospatial User Experience (UX): Industry Shift
Ask HN: What is the future of “third places”?
text:
Third places would be any place other than work and home. Think like cafes, religious institutions, etc. It's a place where you don't have an identity/label tied to you. You just go there to socialize and be with people.

Is the future of third places online? If so, what are some companies making online third places?
